Palladium nanoparticles entrapped in polymeric ionic liquid microgels as recyclable hydrogenation catalysts Yanmei Zhang a b Xian-Yang Quek a Leilei Wu a Yejun Guan a 1 Emiel J. Hensen a ⁎ a Laboratory of Inorganic Materials Chemistry, Schuit Institute of Catalysis, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, Den Dolech 2, 5612 AZ Eindhoven, The Netherlands Laboratory of Inorganic Materials Chemistry, Schuit Institute of Catalysis, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven Den Dolech 2 AZ Eindhoven 5612 The Netherlands b College of Life Science, Dalian Nationalities University, Economical and Technological Development Zone, Dalian 116600, China College of Life Science, Dalian Nationalities University, Economical and Technological Development Zone Dalian 116600 China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Present address: Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, Department of Chemistry, East China Normal University, North Zhongshan Road 3663, 200032 Shanghai, China. Graphical abstract Metallic Pd nanoparticles with narrow size distributions were prepared in cross-linked ionic liquid polymers (microgels). The microgels support Pd nanoparticles and prevent their aggregation. Size control of the Pd nanoparticles in polymers is possible by varying the metal loading and reduction method. The particle size has a clear effect on the hydrogenation activity of the Pd nanoparticles with 3nm sized ones being most active in styrene hydrogenation. Also the physicochemical properties of the polymeric microgels significantly influence catalytic performance. High activity is obtained when bromide is used as the counterion because of the good swellability of the resulting Pd/microgel catalysts in polar solvents such as methanol. The use of a hydrophobic counterion results in loss of catalytic activity. Furthermore, the microgels supported Pd nanoparticles can be recycled at least ten times without obvious loss of activity. Keywords Pd nanoparticles Polymeric ionic liquid microgels Hydrogenation Recycle 1 Introduction Metallic nanoparticles have attracted considerable attention in recent years because of their high catalytic performance in many reactions due to their high surface to volume ratio [1–3]. However, applications with suspended metallic nanoparticles are limited, because the naked nanoparticles tend to aggregate resulting in severe decrease of catalytic activity and often also selectivity [4]. An effective way to resolve this problem is to stabilize the nanoparticles by use of capping agents or to immobilize them on a support. Many methods have been developed for this purpose [5–8]. Besides particle size, the nanoparticle–stabilizer interaction is one of the pivotal factors determining catalytic performance. Generally, catalytic activity is low if the interaction is very strong due to blocking of surface sites, while a too weak interaction fails to stabilize the nanoparticles resulting in undesired agglomeration. In recent years, ionic liquids (ILs) have been explored as stabilizers for metallic nanoparticles. Imidazolium-based ionic liquids can indeed stabilize nanoparticles electrostatically as well as by coordination involving bulky imidazolium cations [4,9]. There are already many publications reporting that IL-stabilized metallic nanoparticles exhibit high activity and selectivity in catalysis [9–12]. It is a potent field as the ionic liquid can also be tailored by introducing functionalities that interact with nanoparticles [12]. However, stabilization solely by ILs still has some limitations. For instance, it has been shown that Pd will leach into solution when suspending palladium-N-heterocyclic carbene complexes into IL solvents [1]. Moreover, difficulties in separation and reuse also limit their use. An alternative method to stabilize nanoparticles is their immobilization onto a solid support, which facilitates recycling. This is the most common method used in heterogeneous catalysis. Examples of solid supports are carbon [13], metal oxides [14] such as silica [15] or crystalline frameworks such as zeolite [16], polymer resins [17], and metal–organic frameworks [18]. However, also in this case immobilization often results in significant loss of catalytic activity due to the strong interaction between the support and the nanoparticles. In this respect, it is noteworthy that solid materials containing imidazolium cations may favourably interact with metallic nanoparticles such that good catalytic performance is obtained, whilst allowing recycling of the supported nanoparticles by centrifugation or filtration [10,19–26]. Till to date, there are only few examples involving cross-linked polymers having the chemical structure of ionic liquids. Most of these polymers have been applied as membranes and electrolytes [27–29], with only a very small number of examples in catalysis [23,30]. Palladium is widely used for a significant number of synthetic transformations [31,32]. Herein we report a simple and general synthesis procedure to obtain Pd nanoparticles stabilized by polymeric ionic liquid microgels and their evaluation as heterogeneous catalysts for hydrogenation reactions. These new catalysts exhibit excellent turnover frequencies, selectivity, and reusability for hydrogenation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of materials The microgels were prepared by a water-in-oil emulsion method with Span 80 as surfactant and dodecane as co-solvent. The dispersed aqueous phase consists of 1.8g 1-vinyl-3-ethylimidazolium bromide or 1-vinyl-3-methanamineimidazolium bromide, 90mg N,N′-methylene bisacrylamide (cross-linking agent, corresponds to a cross-linking degree of 5%), 40mg ammonium persulfate (initiator), 2.5mL phosphate buffer solution (pH=6). The continuous phase consists of 0.25g Span 80 and 5mL dodecane. The emulsion is prepared by dropwise addition with a syringe of the dispersed phase into the continuous phase under magnetic stirring. A concentrated gel-like emulsion is obtained, which is then purged with nitrogen to remove residual oxygen. The polymerization is started by addition of N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylethylenediamine (120μL). After 6h of reaction at room temperature, the obtained microparticles are precipitated with acetone, filtrated and washed with distilled water. After this, they are freeze-dried to remove residual solvent. The polymers are denoted as PILs or NH2-PILs. The process for the introduction of Pd nanoparticles into the ionic liquid polymers is schematically shown in Scheme 1 . The metal precursor of Pd was adsorbed by ion-exchange of Br− for PdCl4 2−. Normally, 0.2g of PILs or NH2-PIL was dispersed in water and mixed with the desired amount of a PdCl4 2− solution. The solid was then separated by centrifugation and washed several times by water. Finally, the Pd cations were reduced by NaBH4 or H2 in water. After separation and washing, the catalysts were dried and denoted as Pd(x)/PIL-Br or Pd(x)/NH2-PIL-Br, with x being the Pd loading as determined by ICP-OES analysis. 2.2 Catalytic activity measurements The reaction was performed in a 10mL stainless-steel reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer. In a typical hydrogenation experiment, catalyst and 0.2g of styrene together with 5mL of methanol were mixed and air was replaced by H2. The reactor was filled with H2 until the pressure was 10bar. The reaction was started by stirring at room temperature. After the reaction, the filtrate was analysed by gas chromatography (QP5050, Shimadzu) equipped with a Rxi-5ms capillary column (30m×0.25mm×0.5μm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). 2.3 Characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D4 Endeavour using Cu Kα (λ =0.15405nm) radiation at 40kV and a current of 40mA. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Thermo Nicolet Nexus 470 Fourier Transform infrared spectrometer. Scanning electronic microscopy (SEM) images were recorded on Quanta 3D FEG instrument. The size and morphology of the Pd nanoparticles were determined by a Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscopy (TEM) operated at an acceleration voltage of 200kV with a LaB6 filament. Samples were obtained by placing a drop of a colloidal solution onto a carbon-coated copper grid and evaporation of the solvent in air at room temperature. 3 Results and discussion Supported ionic liquids are promising stabilizers for metallic nanoparticles and Pd nanocatalysts were studied extensively in hydrogenation reactions [33–38]. Therefore, Pd nanoparticles entrapped into polymeric ionic liquids were prepared by following the synthetic approach outlined in Scheme 1. Briefly, a vinyl functionalized ionic liquids precursor was prepared and used as starting material to prepare cross-linked polymers by radical polymerization. Then, PdCl4 2− was loaded by ion-exchange with Br−. The metal salt was further reduced to obtain nanoparticles using hydrogen or sodium borohydride. The final Pd loadings and the average particle size were determined by ICP and TEM, respectively. The results are summarized in Table 1 . The chemical structure of the PILs was characterized by FT-IR (Fig. 1 ). Bands in the range of 2800–3000cm−1 originate from the linear CH2 CH2 groups attached to the imidazolium rings. Features at 1550cm−1 and 1650cm−1 as well as bands above 3000cm−1 are from the CH and CC vibrational modes of the imidazolium rings [4]. After ion-exchange and reduction, a shift of the band at 1650cm−1 is observed. This is most likely caused by the interaction of the metal nanoparticles with the CC groups in the ionic liquid. Overall, the spectra are very similar before and after reduction indicating that the structure of PILs remains intact. The Pd/PIL-Br catalysts were also characterized by XRD. Fig. 2 shows that before and after ion-exchange a broad amorphous feature is present between 20 and 30°. After reduction by NaBH4 or H2, the solid exhibits characteristic peaks at angles (2θ) of 40.2, 46.7, 68.3, 82.2 and 86.7°, corresponding to (111), (200), (220), (311) and (307) planes, respectively, of fcc metals [22]. It is also seen that the peak intensities increase with Pd loading. As expected, the diffraction peaks become broader at low loading due to decreasing size of the nanoparticles. The effect of the reduction method was also investigation. When instead of NaBH4 the Pd precursor anions were reduced in H2 with methanol as the solvent, much larger Pd particles were obtained. The morphology of the PILs was further studied with SEM. Fig. 3 shows representative SEM micrographs, which indicate that the particle size is around 25μm and the particles are not damaged during the following Pd loading process. In general, the materials also contain a small fraction of smaller particles. The EDX data (not shown here) give the elemental composition before and after introduction of the Pd. It follows that part of Br− was replaced by Pd and the Pd loading corresponds well to the results by ICP element analysis (Table 1). Moreover, the presence of P and F elements indicates the presence of the PF6 − after exchange with this ion. TEM was used to determine the size and size distribution of Pd nanoparticles entrapped in the microgels. As can been seen in Fig. 4 , at a loading of 2.8wt%, the average particle size is 1.8nm and the nanoparticles are well dispersed. When the loading is increased to 5.5wt%, the average particle size is around 2.1nm. Pd loadings of 10wt% and 28wt% result in average particles sizes of 3.3nm and 3.6nm, respectively. Furthermore, when hydrogen was used for reduction instead of NaBH4, the average particle size is around 7.3nm for the sample with a loading of 28wt%. Amine groups have strong affinity to Pd nanoparticles [39,40]. Therefore, amine-functionalized PILs were also used to entrap Pd nanoparticles. The Pd loadings were 5.1 and 10wt% with average nanoparticle sizes of 3.5 and 5.0nm, respectively. To investigate the effect of the physical and chemical properties of polymeric ionic liquids on catalysis, the catalysts were further exchanged with PF6 − to render the materials hydrophobic. As shown in Table 1, the Pd particle remains unchanged during the exchange process. Pd-catalysed hydrogenation is of significant importance in modern synthetic chemistry [4,41]. Styrene hydrogenation in methanol was used as a model reaction to evaluate the catalytic activity of the entrapped Pd nanoparticles. This solvent was chosen because the bromide-containing PILs swell well in methanol. The results are summarized in Table 1. A blank experiment did not show any styrene conversion. There was also no styrene conversion without Pd species in the microgel (not shown), indicating the hydrogenation activity is from the Pd nanoparticles and not from the polymer components. The influence of particle size on the hydrogenation of olefinic bonds is of great industrial interest. As can be seen in Table 1, our results show a significant size effect on the catalytic activity for styrene hydrogenation. The TOF is highest for Pd(10%)/PIL-Br(NaBH4) with an intermediate particle size of 3.3nm. A catalyst with a much larger particle size produced by reduction of the precursor in H2 in methanol (average diameter 7.3nm) showed a much lower TOF of only 1656h−1. From these findings, we conclude that the styrene hydrogenation reaction is structure sensitive with optimal particle size being around 3nm. In general, hydrogenation of double bonds is not considered to be structure sensitive. We can only speculate that the interaction of the Pd nanoparticles with the ionic liquid environment brings about this peculiar effect. Earlier, we have shown that suspending metal nanoparticles in an ionic liquid solvent may totally suppress their hydrogenation activity [42]. Finally, to verify that the supported Pd nanoparticles and not leached Pd catalyse styrene hydrogenation, we filtered Pd(10%)/PIL-Br(NaBH4) after 5min of reaction and added fresh styrene to the filtrate. After 5min of reaction, we determined that styrene had not been further converted. This result is in line with the finding that the Pd concentration in the filtrate is below the ICP detection limit for this particular measurement of 1μg Pd/g solution. It is not only the size of the nanoparticle that has significant effect on catalysis, interaction between the nanoparticle and the support is also important. Strong interaction with the support may lower the activity of the Pd nanoparticles. When the Pd nanoparticles are entrapped in an amine-functionalized support, the activity (TOF=3600h−1) is only slightly affected compared to the non-amine-containing PILs supported catalysts (TOF=4800h−1) under the otherwise similar reaction conditions. Besides optimum particle size, accessibility of the Pd nanoparticles entrapped in the polymeric gel particle is a key prerequisite for good catalytic performance. Therefore, the control over the morphology and physical properties of the polymers is important. The physical and chemical properties of ionic liquids can be varied over a wide range by proper selection of cations and anions. The presence of strongly coordinating anions such as chloride or bromide results in hydrophilicity of the PILs. When the anion is replaced by hexafluorophosphate, hydrophobicity is conferred to the PILs. Microscopy was used to evidence the significant swelling ability of the Br−-containing PILs in polar solvents, such as water and methanol (not shown here). This swelling behaviour did not occur in THF nor in cyclohexane. In line with this difference, Pd(10%)/PIL-Br shows high hydrogenation activity in methanol, whereas almost no activity was observed in THF and cyclohexane (Table 2 ). It is speculated that the lower accessibility of the substrate to the Pd nanoparticles in the two latter cases causes the low activity. Also, the PILs became hydrophobic when Br− was replaced by PF6 − and, accordingly, could not swell in methanol. Also in this case, no catalytic activity was detected. Whereas microscopy confirmed the immediate swelling of Br-containing PILs, those exchanged with PF6 − did not change their morphology and size. Accordingly, it is inferred that direct accessibility of substrates due to swelling of the PILs is essential for the catalytic performance of these PILs-supported Pd nanoparticles. These findings also evidence that the hydrogenation reaction occurs inside the microgel particles where Pd nanoparticles are stabilized by the ionic liquids groups. In summary, the Pd nanoparticles are entrapped inside the polymers and their activities are tunable by changing solvents or the counter ions of the PILs. Pd is known to selectively reduce double and triple CC bonds in the presence of CO bonds [43,44]. By comparing different substrates (Table 3 ), we found that this also holds for the PIL-supported Pd catalysts. For instance, when cyclohexenone is used as the substrate, only the CC bond is hydrogenated, leaving the CO bond unaffected. Also, a substrate only containing a CO double bond was not reduced. Therefore, it is concluded that these catalysts can efficiently catalyse the selective reduction of CC in the presence of CO bonds. The selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene is important from the industrial perspective because a small amount of phenylacetylene in the feed stream can deactivate styrene polymerization processes [45]. Polymer-supported Pd is selective in the semi-hydrogenation of phenylacetylene to styrene. To establish whether these catalysts can indeed be recycled, it was attempted to separate the PILs-supported catalysts from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. The recycling process was straightforward and involved separation by centrifugation, twice washing in methanol, and after redispersing the catalyst in the same solvent a new catalytic test. The recycling experiments for styrene hydrogenation for ten cycles showed no significant loss in activity or selectivity as shown in Table 3. The small loss after 10 recycles might be due to a small loss in dispersion as indicated by the increased particle size following from an XRD measurement (not shown). 4 Conclusions Metallic Pd nanoparticles were successfully prepared in a cross-linked ionic liquid (imidazolium) polymer microgel network. Pd is introduced by ion-exchange of the counter ions of the ionic liquid fragments with PdCl4 2−. Reduction is preferably done by NaBH4. When these microgel particles are swollen in an appropriate solvent (methanol), the embedded Pd nanoparticles can be used for hydrogenation of CC double and triple bonds. The cross-linked ionic liquid polymers serve both as support and stabilizer for the Pd nanoparticles, preventing extensive aggregation. Size control of the Pd nanoparticles in polymers is possible by varying the loadings and the reduction method. The optimum Pd nanoparticle size is ∼3nm. In solvents that do not swell the microgel particles such as THF, the activity is lost. Also, when the hydrophilic Br anion is replaced by the hydrophobic PF6 − one, the microgel particles cannot swell with concomitant loss of activity. The selectivity of Pd catalysts in selective CC over CO hydrogenation was retained for the microgel-embedded Pd nanoparticles. The Pd nanoparticles stabilized in a polymeric ionic liquid gel matrix can be recycled for at least 10 times without obvious loss of activity. coredata.dc:description: Metallic Pd nanoparticles with narrow size distributions were prepared in cross-linked ionic liquid polymers (microgels). The microgels support Pd nanoparticles and prevent their aggregation. Size control of the Pd nanoparticles in polymers is possible by varying the metal loading and reduction method. The particle size has a clear effect on the hydrogenation activity of the Pd nanoparticles with 3nm sized ones being most active in styrene hydrogenation. Also the physicochemical properties of the polymeric microgels significantly influence catalytic performance. High activity is obtained when bromide is used as the counterion because of the good swellability of the resulting Pd/microgel catalysts in polar solvents such as methanol. The use of a hydrophobic counterion results in loss of catalytic activity. Furthermore, the microgels supported Pd nanoparticles can be recycled at least ten times without obvious loss of activity.
coredata.dc:title: Palladium nanoparticles entrapped in polymeric ionic liquid microgels as recyclable hydrogenation catalysts
